div1.p: Carter and Brown are working hard to keep up with Frost's timeline for completion of the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 3, 1928
div1.opener:
Book- Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
November 3, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have completed another satisfactory and in-
tensive weeks work, Miss Brown using therefor some of the small re-
mainder of her annual leave, her lunch time, from the closing of the
Library at 4.30 and at night. This, of course, is pretty strenuous, but
we are extremely anxious not only to keep up with Dr. Frost, but to have
our material worked up well ahead of the time that he is liable to call
for it. This has been difficult, because some books, with references having
an important bearing on the arguments in Father's work, have only re-
cently become available to us, and to verify their text and get the
pagination means that we must utilize every available moment. This
we are certainly doing.

Miss Brown much appreciated the check for her work for October.
She will continue to work on the bibliography without remuneration
just so long as her services are needed. Of the value of theseher ser-
vices I cannot speak too highly, nor of her unselfish devotion and
enthusiasm for the work.

Dr. Frost writes that he shall probably want me to work with
him in Baltimore for several days next week.
div1.closer:
With best remembrances, I remain
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
